text: Dear all, a few updated about the issue on “doubling effect”; as suggested, I`ve tested different settings and I can see the “doubling” even if just using one sheet (central one) and in the single raw data of a dynamic focus dataset. So, it seems that is something related to the sample (or the agar) that can make a kind of “reflection” of the image; that`s what we conclude discussing also with the Lavision support; and I can`t find better explanation and is an issue that is hard to replicate (fortunately); I`ve anyone has better ideas, I`ll close the issue and try to cope with that.

text:
The funny thing is that, while doing these test we found some other issues with Dynamic Focus..basically 1.
Sometimes only one side of the image is acquired with DF (one side is faint); it is generally solved by unclicking “blend over mosaic width”; anyone had the same issue? Solutions?
2.
I can see some stripes on the samples (see attach image), corresponding very likely to the position of the sheet waist; only visible when there is a dense and regular biological pattern (cell bodies); it is not a dramatic issue, but: anyone know how to solve it (= have a more homogenous signal)? Maybe need to do more/less steps (than the ones suggested)?
3.
Even if system is well aligned (checking carefully the beam on the sample) I can see the DF using one side (RIGHT) gives much better better than the other (LEFT); effect visible well visible in Y projection. Seems the that final image is made up not using the brightest part of each image/DF step; maybe is an image fusion issue more than a calibration issue?..It is just a bit scary, because the loss of quality is significant and I`m wondering if it is really safer to use the “column tiling” approach used by Renier Lab (as already proposed by Pablo..); <https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/32059781/>
Any feedback or suggestions are welcome! Thanks; full report with images can be found here <https://www.dropbox.com/s/xjhsq9h34a00mkj/201123_Lavision_report_Crick.pptx.pdf?dl=0>
